subject: PREPARING A CORRECT PATH
verse: Teach your children to choose the right  path, and when they are older, they will  remain upon it. (Proverbs 22:6)
reflection:
In the process of helping our children “choose the right path,” we must discern differing paths for each child. It is natural to want to bring up all our children alike or train them the same way. This verse im- plies that parents should discern the individ- uality and special strengths that God has
given each one. While we should not con- done or excuse self-will, each child has natural inclinations that parents can develop. By talking to teachers, other parents, and grandparents, we can better discern and develop the individual capabilities of each child.
prayer: Give thanks for your Christian education and pray to the Lord Jesus to nurture you in the faith.

subject: GETTING TO KNOW JESUS BETTER
verse: O hope of Israel, its Savior in time of distress, why are you like a stranger in the land, like a traveler who stays only a night? (Jeremiah 14:8)
reflection:
What we have here is a paradox, a yes-and-no situation. Yes, many in Jerusalem recognized Jesus, but they really didn’t know Him. To some He was an imposter, a trouble maker, or a mere teacher and would-be-healer.
To a relative few He was the Mes-siah and Son of God revealed. For a relative few, John wrote, “He was in the world, and though the world was made through Him, the world did not recognize Him” (John 1:10). He remained a stranger and a Traveler just passing through.
prayer: Beg the Holy Spirit to reveal Christ Jesus more clearly to you as you study God’s Word.

subject: GOD'S LOVE IS TOTAL
verse: May you have the power to understand,  as all God’s people should, how wide,  how long, how high, and how deep His  love really is. (Ephesians 3:18)
reflection:
We can draw strength for the power and love that exceeds the pressure of all earthly affliction: God’s love for us in Christ. We can sing, “Oh the height of Jesus’ love, higher than the heav’ns above, deeper than the depth of sea, lasting to eternity!
Love that found me—wonderous thought—found me when I sought Him not.” This truth is based on the testimony of one who was found by Jesus, although he was not seeking Him. Paul knew firsthand the dimensions of Christ’s love. He wrote
that we may try to grasp its dimensions, but Christ’s love for us is beyond our comprehension. It is a love that “surpasses knowledge” (Ephesians 3:19). In Christ “We have redemption through His blood, the forgiveness of sins, in accordance with the riches of God’s grace. (Ephesians 1:7)
prayer: Give thanks and praise to your Savior for His boundless love.

subject: GOD WATCHES OVER US

reflection:

God sent His beloved Son into the world to redeem all its inhabitants from sin and the fear of death. He also redeemed them for something---for a purposeful life here and now and for eternal life. So when we see the song birds leave and other changes
each fall, we can be assured of God’s unchanging love for us and His constant presence with us.
prayer: Let us remember to pray the lines of the hymn “Abide with Me.”

The book of James emphasizes faith in action. Right living is the evidence and result of faith.The church must serve with compassion, speak lovingly and truthfully, live in obedience to God’s commands and love one another. prayer: Give thanks to God for every sinner who repents and believes in Jesus as Savior.

subject: A CHANGE OF VOCATION
verse: “Come, follow me,” Jesus said, “and I will make you  fishers of men.” (Mark 1:17)
reflection:
While some are wishing for the church to somehow grow, others are preparing themselves to be instruments of God in church growth as “fishers of men” (Mark 1:17)
Some Christians in our time feel called to leave what they are doing—to quit their day jobs—so they can concentrate all their energies on missions They become full time fishers of people. But it is not the Lord’s will that we all do this. Some of Christ’s disciples continue in their roles as fishermen, farmers, mechanics, business executives, teachers, nurses, secretaries, and housewives.
In so doing, we fulfill the over- all Christian vocation of being Christ’s witnesses wherever we live and work.
prayer: Pray that Christian missionaries through- out the world may win many souls for Christ, the world’s Savior.

subject: SPIRITUA;L RICHES
verse: “Blessed are you who are poor, for yours  is the kingdom of God.” (Luke 6:20)
reflection:
Our Lord was saying, in effect, that spirit- ual poverty brings great riches: the king- dom of God. Spiritual poverty means hav- ing no great works to show, no high stand- ing, no merit of which to boast. It is, how- ever, a poverty that is rich in faith that looks to Jesus Christ for salvation, which is repent-ance and its fruits.
In the temple the boasting Pharisee was a spiritual pauper, but the pub-lican, who said, “God, have mercy on me, a sinner” (Luke 18:13) was spiritually rich. He “went home justified by God” (Luke 18:14).
prayer: Ask the Holy Spirit that you may be enrich- ed in all spiritual treasures: forgiveness, the fruit of the Spirit, the promise of eternal life.

subject: HEALING WATER
verse:
[God]
saved us through the washing of  rebirth and renewal by the Holy Spirit. (Titus 3:5)
reflection:
Our Lord Jesus used water for spiritual healing when He instituted the Sacrament of Baptism. The Word and the waters of Baptism heal spiritually because the Holy Spirit works through it. It causes a sinner, even a very young one, to come to saving faith. In Baptism, the water and the Word flow like a refresh-ing, healing spring, bringing with it all that our Savior earned for us on the cross:
forgiveness of sins, life, salvation, and spiritual renewal.
prayer: Let us give thanks to the Triune God, into whose name we were baptized, for making us one of His beloved children.
